author: metachris_
content:
>  The only necessary data on that request is the execution_payload_header which includes the block_hash used to know which block to return.
Fyi, that's not enough - the relay also need to verify the proposer. See the mev-boost audit chapter "Relayer SignedBlindedBeaconBlock validation"  https://github.com/flashbots/mev-boost/blob/main/docs/audit-20220620.md#relayer-signedblindedbeaconblock-validation for more details

And yes, the relay should eventually also broadcast the block.

author: .charlescharles
content: I think relay still needs to gossip pretty fast to avoid mev stealing attacks by proposers who control multiple slots in a row

author: .charlescharles
content: Where the block value > slashing cost

author: .charlescharles
content: Eg proposer learns the block body, slashably signs and broadcasts an empty block, and steals the mev in the next block

author: yokem55
content: That seems pretty risky - if the chain settles on the first iteration of the block instead of the slashable empty one, then the strategy is for naught.

author: ajsutton
content: That's why its in the relays interest to publish the final block as quickly as possible - to make it the most likely block to become canonical.  It's also in the beacon node's best interest to publish the block so that it doesn't miss the block proposal if the relay fails to publish it for some reason.  Hence, both should wind up publishing the block.
